'''''The Ruined Enchanter'''''<ref name=collectedpoems>{{CP|62}}</ref> is a poem written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] in [[11 November]] of [[1919]].<ref name=chronology1919>{{CG|C}}, p. 109 (entry "11 November 1919")</ref>

== First stanza ==
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
:Long have I dwelt in Belmarye,
:And fair my garden is to see.
::For walls of magic ring it round,
::And rooted deep in enchanted ground
:There grows a dark enchanted tree.<ref name=collectedpoems/></poem>

== Background ==
On 11 November of 1919, Tolkien wrote an unfinished poem entitled '''''The Ruined Enchanter: A Fairy Ballad'''''<ref name=chronology>{{CG|Po}}, p. 854 (entry "''The Ruined Enchanter: A Fairy Ballad''")</ref> on the verso of a letter from the [[Wikipedia:Ministry of Pensions and National Insurance#Ministry of Pensions|Ministry of Pensions]].<ref name=chronology1919/>

Tolkien later removed the poem's subtitle in a later manuscript.<ref name=collectedpoems/>

In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was published for the first time as entry 62 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''.<ref name=collectedpoems/>

== Inspiration ==
The poem may have been inspired by a [[Wikipedia:I Had a Little Nut Tree|nursery rhyme]] dating to the mid-fifteenth century.<ref name=collectedpoems/>
